summary: Liposarcomas are the most common subtype of soft tissue sarcomas, arising from precursor lipoblasts of adipocytes in adipose tissues. They are classified into five forms: atypical lipomatous tumor/well-differentiated liposarcoma, dedifferentiated liposarcoma, myxoid liposarcoma, pleomorphic liposarcoma, and myxoid pleomorphic liposarcoma. While some forms are considered benign or premalignant, all can infiltrate locally, recur after surgery, and metastasize, potentially leading to life-threatening diseases. They are often only marginally responsive to current chemotherapy and radiotherapy regimens.
causes: Genetic mutations (e.g., amplification of MDM2 and CDK4 genes in ALT/WDL and DDL)
Translocations involving FUS-DDIT3 or EWSR1-DDIT3 fusion genes in myxoid liposarcoma
Inactivation of RB1 tumor suppressor gene in myxoid pleomorphic liposarcoma
risk_factors: Hereditary genetic disorders (Li-Fraumeni syndrome, Muir–Torre syndromes) predisposing to various cancers
symptoms: Pain (less common, due to organ impingement)
diagnosis: Genetic findings (e.g., MDM2 or CDK4 gene overexpression, sSMC or giant marker chromosome detection)
Detection of DDIT3 gene rearrangements (FUS or EWSR1) by in situ hybridization or immunohistochemistry (for myxoid liposarcoma)
Absence of FUS-DDIT3 or EWSR1-DDIT3 fusion genes (for myxoid pleomorphic liposarcoma)
treatments: Chemotherapy (e.g., doxorubicin, ifosfamide, gemcitabine, docetaxel, eribulin, trabectedin)
Targeted therapy (e.g., CDK4 or MDM2 gene inhibitors like abemaciclib, ribociclib, milademetan)
